title: Data overview
text: We will be using a variety of real-world data from public sources and published research. You can read the data dictionary for each dataset from the side menu. You will be able to access the data from a dedicated  package {hss8005data} (note: work in progress and may be updated during the course).

title: HSS8005 {{< iconify line-md plus >}}
text:
Quantitative analysis 
        
        
            HSS8005 • Advanced stream • 2023
Newcastle University (UK)
        
        
            A second course in applied statistics and probability for the understanding of society and culture.
        
    




Module leader

   Dr. Chris Moreh
   HDB.4.106
   chris.moreh@newcastle.ac.uk
   tutorial booker



Teaching Assistants

Session details

   Labs:   13:00-14:30 (Group 03)        14:30-16:00 (Group 04)

title: HSS8005 {{< iconify line-md plus >}}
text:
Title


Subtitle


Description






Week 1  Gamblers, God, Guinness and peas


A brief history of statistics


This lecture is a broad introduction to the aims of statistical modeling and the history of probability theory. We will look back on the development of some core statistical concepts and learn about the ideas and preoccupations that influenced them over three centuries. The aim of this overview is to build up essential intuition about the concepts and methods that we will learn about later. The outcome will be a much clearer understanding of the limits of statistical analysis and the dangers of not acknowledging those limits.
The IT labs, on the other hand, will provide a very hands-on practical introduction to the R statistical programming language, its currently most popular dialect, the {tidyverse}, and its usage in the RStudio application programming interface. The session will also introduce some other tools of literate programming, project management and plain-text social science (such as markdown and Quarto), all essential skills in contemporary quantitative research in the social sciences and humanities.




Week 2  Revisiting Flatland


Revisiting Flatland






Week 3


Dear Prudence, Help! I may be cheating with my X






Week 4


The Y question






Week 5


Do we live in a simulation?






Week 6


Challenging hierarchies






Week 7


The unobserved






Week 8


Words! Mere words!








No matching items

title: Week 1  Gamblers, God, Guinness and peas
text: The labs will be an introduction to the {tidyverse} dialect of the  statistical programming language via the  API.

title: Week 2  Revisiting Flatland
text: A broad review of simple linear regression modelling.

title: Week 3
text: Introduction/review of linear regression models with more than one predictor, with a focus on the concept of causation in a regression context and the use of directed acyclic graphs (DAG) as heuristic devices.

title: Week 4
text: An introduction to generalised linear models; logistic and count models.

title: Week 5
text: An introduction to the idea and elementary practice of statistical simulation.

title: Week 6
text: Introduction to time-series, maybe some spatial correlation and multilevel data amd models.

title: Week 7
text: Introduction to factor analysis and Structural Equation Models (SEM).

title: Week 8
text: Introduction to (social) network analysis and a little text analysis.

Please note that this plan and the content are still work in progress. The info sheets under  are available in a very rudimentary form, just to give some more boring details about how these planned topics map on to statistical methods that will be covered. The topics marked with an * have a very borderline-significant p-value when tested on the null-hypothesis that they have 0 probability of actually being covered in practice. It will depend somewhat on our interests and the pace of our progress through the previous topics.

title: Readings
text:
General and Generalised Linear models

I found this page on The General Linear Model (GLM) quite easy to read.
And this one on [Generalised Linear Models](https://www.mygreatlearning.com/blog/generalized-linear-models/#:~:text=Generalized%20Linear%20Model%20(GLiM%2C%20or,other%20than%20a%20normal%20distribution.):

What is a Generalized Linear Model?
Generalized Linear Model (GLiM, or GLM) is an advanced statistical modelling technique formulated by John Nelder and Robert Wedderburn in 1972. It is an umbrella term that encompasses many other models, which allows the response variable y to have an error distribution other than a normal distribution. The models include Linear Regression, Logistic Regression, and Poisson Regression.
In a Linear Regression Model, the response (aka dependent/target) variable 'y' is expressed as a linear function/linear combination of all the predictors 'X' (aka independent/regression/explanatory/observed variables). The underlying relationship between the response and the predictors is linear (i.e. we can simply visualize the relationship in the form of a straight line). Also, the error distribution of the response variable should be normally distributed. Therefore we are building a linear model.
GLM models allow us to build a linear relationship between the response and predictors, even though their underlying relationship is not linear. This is made possible by using a link function, which links the response variable to a linear model. Unlike Linear Regression models, the error distribution of the response variable need not be normally distributed. The errors in the response variable are assumed to follow an exponential family of distribution (i.e. normal, binomial, Poisson, or gamma distributions). Since we are trying to generalize a linear regression model that can also be applied in these cases, the name Generalized Linear Models.
